												The game has an interesting concept and was the first Greenlight title.  Take a typical RPG setting and control the town instead of the heroes.  Your job is to build up sufficient infrastructure to attract and keep heroes happy for...some reason.  Who knows.Most of the 36 hours I spent playing were staring at the game in frustration trying to get it to work.  It has some similarities to Dwarf Fortress but it felt like I didn't have as much control.As others have said, get Gnomoria instead.  Cannot recommend this game to anyone.However I must give Towns at least a 1/10.  Due to its incredibly broken and frustrating nature, I had to look up help on YouTube and that led me to discovering Sips for the first time.  So thank you Towns for helping me find one of my favorite YouTubers.

content:
er 31, 2012
												In a word, Unfinished.In many -- Towns is a promising, but rough experience. Nothing seems to work quite as intended, the UI is a little finicky, mouse clicks don't always register in the right place (if at all), and digging is a nightmare. The further down you dig, the more erratic the mouse behavior becomes.At 15$, I'd say the price is steep -- comparing to Minecraft, which released at a similar price, the level of functionality is far less. Though then again, the requisite functionality is far greater in the case of Towns. However, this game is flawed for a far simpler reason, it was released onto steam with no notice that it was an unfinished, alpha game -- I'm an alpha-player, I love to play and watch as a game evolves, and I am _more likely_ to purchase an alpha game than many non-alpha games. I know many of my friends feel the same way, but  this game released to steam (via Greenlight) purporting to be a fully-ready 1.0 release, and that's just not what it is.I say wait. Maybe get it if the price drops to the 2-5$ range. It has potential to be quite good, if the development continues, but everything about the more general practice smells of a smash and grab on my wallet, and I don't much care for it.Weak accept on potential, Strong Reject on Honesty.

content:
3, 2014
												I'll keep this short, This game has a learning curve thats quite steep, and it will be about 3 games before you figure out the basics. By the time you have a thriving town that can sustain itself you'll feel very acomplished. Soon though, things stop being so rewarding. Your townies are irritating at best, they can die from starvation because they straded themself 2 blocks high wile building, or drown because their path took them into water. Your buildings will very quickly trade estetics for fuctionality, possibaly a gribe for someone only as perfectionist as myself. There is nothing really to do after you figured everything out, because besides for a stray orge or something random like that the challenge is gone.I'm not saying not to buy this game, if its on sale by all means buy it, the learning curve wile give you enough entirtainment at least. But, this game is buggy and unpolished, and updates are nearly non existant, so it is a risk.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
er 6, 2013
												I bought Towns on sale just over a year ago...in that time it has received a few updates and undergone some changes.  However, this does not change the fact that this game left an utterly appalling impression upon me not only with the game but with the people working on it.  The tutorials were shamefully unhelpful, the gameplay was unintuitive, and the art style was unique but lead to an overall crude feel due to the games clunky play.As time has passed I'd expected this game to get refined some and updated to assauge some of the issues I had...but to this date the progress has been glacially slow and it remains the same lump of an overcomplicated mess that it always was.  Perhaps I'm being overly spiteful given my own impressions, but I can't for the life of me find any redeeming features about this game after it has remained the same awful product for so long.It's possible that you might enjoy this game, but I would heartily advise in-depth research about it, if not choosing a different product outright.

content:
er 25, 2013
												I originally bought this with the thought of "Woah cool, a town simulator!" in my mind.  After all, the screenshots showed some very epic looking towns, and the game wasn't in the Early Access category. (meaning it wasn't an alpha/beta, but rather a full release)Boy was I in for a surprise.. and not the good kind.I can sum up this game in one single word - Awful.  There was barely a tutorial involved, so I had no idea what I was doing.  I started up a game and within minutes my villagers with their fantastic AI decided to disregard all common sense and took it in turns to throw themselves at a monster, resulting in most of my population dying right away.  Those who survived died of starvation a few in-game days later because I had no idea how I was meant to feed them, despite throwing food down right infront of them.The game is filled with bugs, and there's been very little care and attention given to the game from the devs.  They've tried to pass off this game as being a full release, yet it's clearly still in alpha stage.  There's been many players complaining and demanding answers from the devs, but their cries seem to fall upon deaf ears.  Now that the devs have made a cool $2mil from this game, they couldn't care less, and it clearly shows.Don't buy this game, not even for a laugh/joke.  These developers don't deserve any of your money.

content:
er 15, 2014
												The bottom line:  This game has an interesting premise.  Rather than casting you as the hero who goes into the dungeons in search of fame and glory, you are in charge of building and organizing the town above the dungeon where the hero rents his hotel room and buys his weapons.  That said, this game really isn't as much fun as it sounds.  It is an extensive exercise in MICRO-MANAGEMENT.  If you can get it for REALLY REALLY CHEAP, then it's worth playing if you enjoy games like the original Warcraft (the original, not WoW!!) or Sim City.  I have to say though, I am not a fan of any game where the townsfolk will starve to death if you just leave them alone for a while.You start out with a handful of citizens and absolutely no town.  Your first 4 hours of play will be dedicated to gathering food and setting up a farm so your citizens don't starve to death (which they will do QUITE OFTEN if you are not paying attention!!).  Your next 6 hours of play will be dedicated to mining a few piles of rock and mud, chopping down a few trees, and building some basic workshops for your citizens to work in.  Then you'll spend another 3 hours setting up a kitchen and a bakery, as well as some animal farms so your people can eat something besides apples.  Only after that will you worry about building a tavern for traveling heroes to stay and eat at.  And only after THAT will you start digging down into the dungeon.  Digging into the dungeon and having a tavern with at least one open tavern bedroom are the requirements for heroes to start coming to your town.  Different types of heroes will come based on how deep into the dungeon you are, how many people live in your town, and what type of furniture you have in the tavern bedroom.  Once you do get into the dungeons, there are a ton of monsters which will probably kill everyone who finds their way down the  tunnel.  But there are more resources in the dungeon that you can't find on the surface, like iron, copper, silver, and gold... and you need a ton of those to build better weapons and armor for your city guards.  Meanwhile, you might randomly have a Werepig go berserk on your town and KILL EVERYONE, or you might have a sudden invasion by monsters from the forest and THEY ALL DIE.  But NEVER FORGET... the number one priority AT ALL TIMES has to be food production or else your entire city will starve because the citizens are as stupid as rocks.One good thing about this game is that it is VERY EASY to create mods for it.  You can mess with the amount and placement of various resources, enemies, even mountains and plants.  If you want to get deeper into the config files, you can even change the number of citizens you start with, alter citizen and hero attributes, and even alter enemies to make them easier or harder.

Once you do get into the dungeons, there are a ton of monsters which will probably kill everyone who finds their way down the  tunnel.  But there are more resources in the dungeon that you can't find on the surface, like iron, copper, silver, and gold... and you need a ton of those to build better weapons and armor for your city guards.  Meanwhile, you might randomly have a Werepig go berserk on your town and KILL EVERYONE, or you might have a sudden invasion by monsters from the forest and THEY ALL DIE.  But NEVER FORGET... the number one priority AT ALL TIMES has to be food production or else your entire city will starve because the citizens are as stupid as rocks.One good thing about this game is that it is VERY EASY to create mods for it.  You can mess with the amount and placement of various resources, enemies, even mountains and plants.  If you want to get deeper into the config files, you can even change the number of citizens you start with, alter citizen and hero attributes, and even alter enemies to make them easier or harder.

content:
, 2014
												The game is broken.  Bottem line.Its hard to describe because the game WAS (the devs gave up once they got the $) getting patched so broken things were removed... and then new broken things were added in but here is a list of what I found the most broken.1. Building is not fun.  There is no easy copy and paste for buildings.  And if there is, then it is hidden under the games terrible interface.  It can take a lot of effort of placing certain building blocks in certain orders to build a house with the clunky building controls.  But then if you have to do it at least 20 more times if you want to get townies.  It can take a while.2.  The interface is horrible.  The labels are off.  It just felt clunky.  First you have to click one menu button, then you have to click a sub menu button and find what you want.  Then if its something like wheat and you want it to be bread you have to go into more menus and submenus to find what you want.  The bread making tools and blocks should all be on the same page not scattered around.3.  Your villagers are idiots.  They have no clue how to do anything without dieing.  Horrible monsters attacking?  Don't worry, your villagers will just stand there and die instead of running.  Sometimes they run indoors but most of the time go around doing what they normally do.  Their are even some maps with randomly wandering enemys, I dont have a problem with that but they do it so poorly in Towns.  In the snow maps one stray yeti can just wander on over and kill EVERYONE.  Also they will run though hell and back...to get stone.  I have seen them go on some brave runs just to get a basic resource.  You got to give them credit.  They will stop are nothing to drag that junk back to the stockpile... even if they all die in the process.4.  The monsters that attack your village come out of THIN AIR.  You would think they would come from any dungeon entrances you have but they seem to pop out of midair at times.  5.  Monsters are either really OP or really easy.  I watched a guard kill five slimes once.  Then I watched three guards with iron gear just get massacred by ONE wearpig. (Which is actually a common enemy.  Any normal pig could be a wearpig.)  6.  Hero's are broken.  I must have done EVERYTHING I could think of to attract a hero.  They never come.  They are broken.  That or the system is terrible.  Either way the game dosen't explain things and after browsering the web for a while I still can't get damn Heros.  Worst part is.  You need heros to clear dungeons, but you can never get them it seems.7  The way you make your townies happy is stupid.  They mainly get happy from eating.  Problem is, if you have food that fills them up a lot and dosen't make them eat as often.  YOU GET PUNISHED.  I actally tested this at one point by making bread fill 1500%.  Sure enouth happyness dropped to zero because they were not eating.   You can do a few other things like have badger fights (which seem broken) and put decorations but it seems food is what they want the most.  So remember, just spam cakes.  Anything that actually fills their stomachs is bad.  They don't want to be full.  THey want to be hungry.  Makes zero sense.    8.  Last thing I am going to mention is the dungeons...THEY ARE EVERYWHERE.  It seems I can't dig down at all without hititng a dungeon on most map.s  I just wan't some stone but the game shoves the dungeons everywhere.  They cover the whole map when they should be deep underground and have SMALL entrances.    Now things may have changed since I wrote this but this is what I encountered when I played the game.  And maybe some of the issues I mentioned have easy fixes but there is a problem...THE GAME SHOULD EXPLAIN IT THEN.  There is no tutorial.  Well there claims to be one but it just starts you off on fixed map without telling you much.  You have to find the message log and it tells you to do basic stuff.  Nice they have one at all but it never explains the fine details of the game.  Just the basic crude that I could probably figure out just by expermenting.

3, 2014
												This game is abandoned by the developers so no more updates to fix this buggy pile of ♥♥♥♥. I played this game before it came out on steam (so my hours played is wrong), i was in an area with no internet and had a new computer so i only had towns installed because it looked like a promising game; with awesome stuff to build, nice customization (many blocks and armours) and a cool endgame with adventurers helping your town, but after some hours of playing i'd rather just look at a plain wall for three days. The stuff you see in the screenshots are quite "end game", even the most simple structures, your "townies" will most often sleep eat and work outside because you won't be bothered building houses because the building system is VERRY frustrating because:1. Your townies do not indicate whether or not they can build something unlike Dwarf-Fortress and Gnomoria and your townies can't reach ♥♥♥♥.2. Most building-blocks require some weird-♥♥♥♥ items like slime "stuff" (can't remember name and this game is to horible to back and look) to make some stone bricks. Why? I don't know but it hampers creativity.3. You can't build floors unlike DF or Gnomoria so every story you add you need an extra layer just for floors (this may have canged, it was a long time since i played)There is a solution for the reatching problem and that is "scafolding" a block that can be stood upon, walked troug and climbed up. it's completley free so it feels like cheating using it. In other games that adds a scafolding sort of thing they usually cost resorces because scafolding tends to be realy good for moving around. The scafolding tool has been dubed a "god tool" by the comunity because it is realy OP. Other god tools are things like the ability to drop lava anywhere on the map.At least you can get a lot of hours out of this game, but i would definetly NOT recomend it. Go play Gnomoria (that is 2 euros cheaper), DF (that is free) or any other city builder but definatly DO NOT play Towns.

content:
er 25, 2014
												This game had so much potential. I put a lot of hours into building several towns. While I would not necessarily call this 'abandonware' just yet as there have been updates, the feeling is that it's been put so far on the backburner that we will never see a completed product or, by the time we do, what will be the point? Something better or newer will come out to take it's place.The developer insisted that the product is playable upon time of release, after Early Access was terminated. While the game was playable, the words were decieiving. A playable game should not be released if there are still countless bugs to be fixed and several key features that have not been added to the game.It's such a shame, because the game had great potential and an idea for a somewhat unique mechanic. But I can't recommend this game to anyone, unless you are looking for examples of how a good concept can go bad, learn the idea, and take time to figure out how to improve upon it with your own game. Even if the developer would fix the bugs and implement all originally discussed and intended features as described, I just have no faith in the developer and this game anymore.R.I.P. Towns.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												The game is broken.  Bottem line.Its hard to describe because the game WAS (the devs gave up once they got the $) getting patched so broken things were removed... and then new broken things were added in but here is a list of what I found the most broken.1. Building is not fun.  There is no easy copy and paste for buildings.  And if there is, then it is hidden under the games terrible interface.  It can take a lot of effort of placing certain building blocks in certain orders to build a house with the clunky building controls.  But then if you have to do it at least 20 more times if you want to get townies.  It can take a while.2.  The interface is horrible.  The labels are off.  It just felt clunky.  First you have to click one menu button, then you have to click a sub menu button and find what you want.  Then if its something like wheat and you want it to be bread you have to go into more menus and submenus to find what you want.  The bread making tools and blocks should all be on the same page not scattered around.3.  Your villagers are idiots.  They have no clue how to do anything without dieing.  Horrible monsters attacking?  Don't worry, your villagers will just stand there and die instead of running.  Sometimes they run indoors but most of the time go around doing what they normally do.  Their are even some maps with randomly wandering enemys, I dont have a problem with that but they do it so poorly in Towns.  In the snow maps one stray yeti can just wander on over and kill EVERYONE.  Also they will run though hell and back...to get stone.  I have seen them go on some brave runs just to get a basic resource.  You got to give them credit.  They will stop are nothing to drag that junk back to the stockpile... even if they all die in the process.4.  The monsters that attack your village come out of THIN AIR.  You would think they would come from any dungeon entrances you have but they seem to pop out of midair at times.  5.  Monsters are either really OP or really easy.  I watched a guard kill five slimes once.  Then I watched three guards with iron gear just get massacred by ONE wearpig. (Which is actually a common enemy.  Any normal pig could be a wearpig.)  6.  Hero's are broken.  I must have done EVERYTHING I could think of to attract a hero.  They never come.  They are broken.  That or the system is terrible.  Either way the game dosen't explain things and after browsering the web for a while I still can't get damn Heros.  Worst part is.  You need heros to clear dungeons, but you can never get them it seems.7  The way you make your townies happy is stupid.  They mainly get happy from eating.  Problem is, if you have food that fills them up a lot and dosen't make them eat as often.  YOU GET PUNISHED.  I actally tested this at one point by making bread fill 1500%.  Sure enouth happyness dropped to zero because they were not eating.   You can do a few other things like have badger fights (which seem broken) and put decorations but it seems food is what they want the most.  So remember, just spam cakes.  Anything that actually fills their stomachs is bad.  They don't want to be full.  THey want to be hungry.  Makes zero sense.    8.  Last thing I am going to mention is the dungeons...THEY ARE EVERYWHERE.  It seems I can't dig down at all without hititng a dungeon on most map.s  I just wan't some stone but the game shoves the dungeons everywhere.  They cover the whole map when they should be deep underground and have SMALL entrances.    Now things may have changed since I wrote this but this is what I encountered when I played the game.  And maybe some of the issues I mentioned have easy fixes but there is a problem...THE GAME SHOULD EXPLAIN IT THEN.  There is no tutorial.  Well there claims to be one but it just starts you off on fixed map without telling you much.  You have to find the message log and it tells you to do basic stuff.  Nice they have one at all but it never explains the fine details of the game.  Just the basic crude that I could probably figure out just by expermenting.

												Legitimately one of the biggest disappointments on Steam early access. Let's not kid ourselves- Greenlit games are often half-built engines that never see the light of further development. But this takes the cake. Left sitting here alone since 2013, this game had promise, but was only ever a simple town simulator- and not even a good one. I'm personally so tired of paying for games to be developed in hopes my money will be put to use creating something amazing, and while this had some direction and potential, in the end it was abandoned and we were all quite honestly ♥♥♥♥ed for supporting it. Don't buy this piece of ♥♥♥♥.

content:
ry 17, 2014
												I don't have much to say about the gameplay of this game since I gave up on it a couple of months earlier, for it's buggy, controls are tedious, often gives you literally instant death starts, and the graphics are just outright horrendous, reminiscent of cheap point-and-click adventure games. And most importantly - the developers gave up too. It has been at least five full months since the latest update. When you flood the market with thousands of greenlit indie, early access games, there're bound to be duds. I understand that this game was still early in development when I got it and things indeed might turn sour since life is so unpredictable, but it's still so frustrating that what you bought at a real game's price suddenly went silent with updates without giving any real explanation beforehand.For all intents and purposes we could say that this game is effectively dead now. Consider getting Gnomoria if you liked this game's concept, it's currently in active development and even though the dev "team" seems to be just one man, he (or she?) at least gives consistent weekly updates with real content and interacts with players regularly.

content:
, 2013
												The idea of this game is kind of cool.  Unfortunatly that is all this game really is, an idea.  There are a lot of unfinished game-play mechancis. you know, interesting ideas, that just do not go anywhere.For the most part, you start a town, get your food production going and then you need to attract heros to clear out the gaint dungeon undernearth your town.  So what do you end up doing with most of your time once you get past the startup phase?You just watch the heroes bumble around and try and clear out one level of the dungeon.  And when they are done with that?  You just get to watch them do the same thing on the next level.  Thats all you do. Oh sure, you can build stuff for the sake of building stuff, like a garden or place decortave statues, but something really useful?  No.My reccomendation is to NOT buy this game.  Maybe in a few years the game-play will be fleshed out more, but right now, there isn't much, if any, of a game here.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
r 14, 2015
												0/10Do not buy Towns.  It has ripped off too many people.Towns is a game about building a village for simulated RPG adventurers. Reading about all the features it had and all the downloads, I figured I would throw in my $5 and play. This is 2013 by the way. Unfortunately, the game was unplayable. With a glitchy interface and the inability to even pass the tutorial or even build one room.A few months passed from August 2013 and Steam decides to release Green Light, I service indicating which games are incomplete but still up for purchase. To my surprise, Towns was lumped into the newly founded category. Basically, I bought a game I did not know was incomplete. The optimistic side of me thought that Towns would be complete some time in the future.Fast forward a year to 2014 and I see news that Towns developers gave up on ever finishing the game. Meaning they simply took off with my money.http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/217154/Alphafunded_Steam_game_Towns_abandoned_by_devs.phpUpon hearing the news, I was again disappointed. The following year, Steam released a refund policy. I was excited to read that they would allow refunds that were within 14 days with less than one hour of play time. Given that I have clocked a whopping, miserable 19 minutes on Towns, I figured I could do one last attempt.... DENIED.So here I am, writing about how much I have been ripped off from buying the game Towns. It was $5 sure, but I didn't know it was incomplete at the time and Steam fails to acknowledge their mistake.I hope this is the right forum to post to because quite frankly, I feel people should know the darker side that is Steam.Moral of the story.DO NOT BUY TOWNS

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												I so wanted to see this game finished. As it stands, there are far too many bugs in it and the AI periodically commits suicide doing dumb stuff forcing you to repetitively micro manage everything. Imagine the old sims games where you had to tell your sims to go to the bathroom or they ♥♥♥♥ their pants, now imagine the old sims games where you had to micro manage 50 sims spreadout in a ridiculously huge area trying to click on them to each tell them to go take a ♥♥♥♥ before they ♥♥♥♥ their pants.I dunno where I am going with this, all I know is that the devs have abandoned the game and are treating all the paying customers like absolutely garbage. The game's AI is god awful and lots of seemingly simple things have repetitive and/or unnecessarily time-consuming or drawn-out ways of doing things and you will spend majority of your time making sure your AI don't kill themselves by being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.The micro management doesn't only involve the AI, just controlling your resources is a massive headache. As a person who has programmed several Unity games, one of them ended up with 2 million plays, I have absolutely no idea what possessed the developer to take this game in such a sensely complex direction. I can understand that not all game programmers are 'game designers' and are incapable of seeing the flaws in their design, but ♥♥♥♥ at least run it by a friend who can give you honest feedback. This game went horribly wrong at the beginning and the dev likely abandoned it due to needing to spend too much work redoing 90% of the game to make it actually make sense.

content:
9, 2014
												If Gabe were as awesome as we'd like to believe, he'd give us a $15 voucher for another game. The best analogy I can come up with:Gaben is a wealthy pharmacist. He knows his job is to acquire new prescriptions for his large community. Now, there are so many new drugs coming out every day, that Gaben has to ask his community, "What new drugs should we offer at the pharmacy?"The community heard some neat things about this Townsicol, a do-everything drug. Gaben can only assume that his community knows what they want, even though they don't often know how to get the information about the pharmaceutical companies that made the drug, at least not as profieciently as Gaben. The people assure Gaben that yes, we want Townsicol in the pharmacy!So Gaben orders Townsicol, even though it hasn't gone through proper FDA qualifications.The people buy up their prescriptions of their new drug and GOSH! IT TASTES AWFUL! OH GOD! IT'S GIVEN ME DYSENTERY! WHY GA-BGLALARBGB-BEN WHY-ARHGBLARBL?!But Gaben, watching his customers launch projectile vomit at one another, is distressed. He feels bad for his customers, but THEY ASKED FOR THIS. He brought it in as a special order and the man that sold it to him has completely disappeared like some peddler pushing snake oil! Worse, there are those, like yours truly, that watched everyone throw up, walked through that lake of vomit, waded to the counter in all the puke they had expelled, and bought a bottle of Townsicol for themselves.TL;DR game's bad; developers ran with the money; don't buy it, ♥♥♥♥♥.

												The idea of this game was something i couldn't ignore. Sadly, i should have. Bugs, and lack of any sort of walk through, or starting help. Just to start off with. AI that is more likely to kill itself off at first chance than not, can be very frustrating to say the very least. Beyond that, lets look at a very important aspect of the game.The Dev team. They have dropped the game, and decided to come back, more often than i can believe. The very fact that they decided to drop it even once says a lot. The fact that the hired help, decided to jump ship, because he found out.. there wasn't going to be much of a pay check, says a lot. This is very much a "buyer beware". The game isn't finished. The game according to some news feeds is never going to be finished, and yet the games forums (not steam) says they've decided to work on it... "again"Just save your money, and look towards a different game. I know, i will personally be avoiding any game made by this group in the future.

content:
5, 2014
												Pending an Edit, I might change this in the future.This game has great potential, but it all fades after about 20hrs of gameplay.The early learning curve of the game is very steep. Infact, since there is no ingame help of any kind, you will be going to the internet to figure out some mechanics of this game.Villager path finding is always shortest route, regardless of danger. Hostile NPC's do have random and specific spawns, but more often then not I feel they are hunting me down.Building is somewhat confusing till you get the hang of it. The only drawback is, if you don't build in small sections the game seems to hang on larger designs. The same goes for most the resource managment. Even after giving out specific jobs, and setting priority's all my villagers do is eat and sleep.Fact is, this game has loads of pontential. But fails to deliver. At best this feels like an Alpha Version of a game.I do not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
21, 2014
												Interesting. Where did all the reviews go? Wow. Starting on a blank slate here, maybe?Let's be honest: The premise of Towns is as quirky as it is unique: You build a fantasy town OVER a monster-filled dungeon, so that heroes will come and explore said dungeon- and with your town being endared by the monsters but at the same time able to provide important services to the heroes the game clearly has a tongue-in-cheek approach to both town-building and fantasy tropes in general.Let's be honest: This is an early access game. So you can expect it isn't done yet. It allows you to build a diverse range of buildings and services, and heroes do occasionally pop up and do their thing, and yes, there are monsters.And that is the catch, the premise is really interesting but at this stage, the features that are in don't make for a very interesting game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												Pending an Edit, I might change this in the future.This game has great potential, but it all fades after about 20hrs of gameplay.The early learning curve of the game is very steep. Infact, since there is no ingame help of any kind, you will be going to the internet to figure out some mechanics of this game.Villager path finding is always shortest route, regardless of danger. Hostile NPC's do have random and specific spawns, but more often then not I feel they are hunting me down.Building is somewhat confusing till you get the hang of it. The only drawback is, if you don't build in small sections the game seems to hang on larger designs. The same goes for most the resource managment. Even after giving out specific jobs, and setting priority's all my villagers do is eat and sleep.Fact is, this game has loads of pontential. But fails to deliver. At best this feels like an Alpha Version of a game.I do not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
21, 2014
												Interesting. Where did all the reviews go? Wow. Starting on a blank slate here, maybe?Let's be honest: The premise of Towns is as quirky as it is unique: You build a fantasy town OVER a monster-filled dungeon, so that heroes will come and explore said dungeon- and with your town being endared by the monsters but at the same time able to provide important services to the heroes the game clearly has a tongue-in-cheek approach to both town-building and fantasy tropes in general.Let's be honest: This is an early access game. So you can expect it isn't done yet. It allows you to build a diverse range of buildings and services, and heroes do occasionally pop up and do their thing, and yes, there are monsters.And that is the catch, the premise is really interesting but at this stage, the features that are in don't make for a very interesting game.

content:
5, 2015
												DO NOT BUY!It's remarkable that this game costs $15. It's even more remarkable that the game hasn't simply vanished. Every once in a while, I fire it back up to see if I can approach it from a different angle; maybe I missed something the first 30-40 times I tried playing it. It always ends the same; villagers follow no discernable path, nor can they be directed to follow a reasonable path, villagers will get stuck and eventually die of starvation, basic mobs that roam the surface will overwhelm even 3 or 4 villagers at once, villagers will not retreat if they are wounded, issuing building commands is fruitless, at best, etc.Don't give SMP or the devs the benefit of thinking they've made a good game. They stopped supporting it over 1 year ago and have no intention of ever proceeding with its development and improvement.

												Oh how I wish I didn't have to give this game a negative review. I can tell, that this game, if it were to be finished, would be a game I'd cherish. The aspect of this game, the functionality, the rpg/sandbox/strategy elements of this game are all my cup of tea when it comes to PC games. Unfortunately, I cannot give this "would be" game the approval for others to invest their time and money into. Every feature this game has to offer is unfinished and unpolished. Perhaps because there was a lot of tweaking and additional content planned for this game that have yet to be implemented. I really hope this game isn't dead for good, but it has dug itself into a rut with its massive amounts of negative reviews. I cannot disagree with them. It is wrong for the current developer to sell it as a complete game. Unless this game gets any further development, my negative review shall remain.

												DO NOT BUY!It's remarkable that this game costs $15. It's even more remarkable that the game hasn't simply vanished. Every once in a while, I fire it back up to see if I can approach it from a different angle; maybe I missed something the first 30-40 times I tried playing it. It always ends the same; villagers follow no discernable path, nor can they be directed to follow a reasonable path, villagers will get stuck and eventually die of starvation, basic mobs that roam the surface will overwhelm even 3 or 4 villagers at once, villagers will not retreat if they are wounded, issuing building commands is fruitless, at best, etc.Don't give SMP or the devs the benefit of thinking they've made a good game. They stopped supporting it over 1 year ago and have no intention of ever proceeding with its development and improvement.

content:
y 4, 2013
												Pros: Building your town one block at a time is good fun, and exploring the random environments is enjoyable,Cons: It contains a "happiness" mechanic that rewards you for not playing and -- annoyingly -- forces you to leave the game running on its own for long periods in order to advance well.Certainly worth a look, but lacks the long-term appeal of Terraria.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												I´ve voted "No, i do not recommend this game" but i really would like to say: "Yes!"Why? This game really gave me some good time, cause i like the freedom in which you're able to build up a town, the retroish graphics and the possibility to alter the game due editing some xml files. Unfortunately the problems start right there: Since the engine limits the world to a 64*64 cube, you have to choose between dungeon roaming and building high up in the air, when altering the world generation (only a change in values). Last one is my favorite playstyle... or: would be, if the engine would not getting annoyingly laggy with more than 12 surface leves. There seem to be too many transparent blocks which affects the game as soon as you are giving more than two orders to your Townies. So, i am just not able to build high buildings without having a second lag, a second none, a second lag, a sec.. you get it. And that "really grinds my gears".Also, the menu is crap and the tutorial basically only explains how to move your mouse from left to right and bottom to top. Furthermore, there are some serious bugs, which are a total pain in the a**. Check out the Community Hub's discussion to get an idea of them, it is a long list.And yes, the devs spoofed those who bought this game, cause updates came in irregularily, were minor and the communication to us customers is worth mentioning.At the moment rumors say the devs are looking for someone new to heritage this project. We´ll see.After all Towns is a perfect example for everything which could go wrong with Steam's Greenlight/Early Access policy (or which mechanism else failed).I recommend to keep this game in mind, check for updates and buy it when the ♥♥♥♥♥torm moves on.

There wasn't any official word this was happening: the updates just sort of stopped coming out. This game is dead for no better reason than they didn't want to work on it anymore.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2013
												(Game has been abandoned by the developers at what feels like late alpha / early beta)I haven't really read any of the other reviews, except a quick glance at some of the positives, as I don't want mine to be influenced by them in any way. I will note that many of the positive reviews seem to be accidental recommendations, and Steam needs to remove that as the default option :PSo.. Towns. Well it's a decent base for a game, and I generally enjoyed the parts of it which worked properly, but that's really where it ends. If you try, you can perhaps push 20 hours or so out of the game, but ultimately the bugs and complete lack of content and polish will leave you despairing at the developers, who have abandoned this game.The screenshots paint a pretty picture of flourishing towns and wonderful defenses, but it doesn't really apply to a real game, and you'll find yourself becoming frustrated at how fiddly everything is and how face-palmingly unintelligent the AI is, being almost unable to self regulate their most basic requirements. They almost seem suicidal.. but given the state of the game, I won't hold it against them.Ultimately what you see in the screenshots is pretty much everything, and at it's unlikely best (visually). I strongly resent paying full price for games being brought to market which are late alpha/early beta, especially when the developers dump them and run off with the money because they don't really feel like doing it anymore. That's theft where I come from. I don't think the game was officially an 'Early Access' game? Just Greenlight perhaps, but either way I won't be buying a game until it's fully released from now on, and I wish Steam would pull this game off the store and stop putting it on sale. It's a skeleton of a game and will never be more than that.

												First off, this game is the embodiment of early access games gone wrong. It's terrible when developers don't deliver on every promise, because this game had a lot of potential.That said, the game you see now is complete and wont see any future updates. It is very difficult and takes a long time to progress, which is good. There is definitely replay value as well. The one thing I hate most about this game is how the levels work when you're trying to build everything.Tl;dr- It's good as-is,  but the developer is terrible, so buy it at a discount when you can.
